headline: Gonzaga and Oregon Lead a Historic Final Four
summary: With an emphatic 83-59 victory over Xavier, Gonzaga cast aside almost two decades of near misses to reach the Final Four for the first time. Oregon, who upset top-seeded Kansas, will compete appear for the first time since 1939.

headline: Suspect Surrenders After One Killed in Shooting on Las Vegas Strip
summary: The suspected gunman had barricaded himself inside a double-decker bus, prompting police to partially shut down the Las Vegas Strip—one of the busiest tourist corridors in the U.S.—for four hours.

headline: U.S. Coalition Acknowledges It Carried Out Airstrike That Allegedly Killed Civilians
summary: The U.S.-led coalition fighting Islamic State in Iraq said it carried out the March 17 airstrike against positions in western Mosul corresponding to allegations of scores of civilian casualties.

headline: Obamacare Lives But the Health-Care Bull Is Mortal
summary: The demise of the American Health Care act should please investors for now. However, the risks of changing health policy have shifted rather than evaporated.

headline: EU Papers Over Divisions at 60th Birthday Party
summary: European Union leaders, except British Prime Minister Theresa May, pledged their allegiance to the bloc on the 60th anniversary of its founding, but deep divisions remain over its future after Brexit.

headline: NATO Official Sounds Alarm on Russia Libya Role
summary: Russia’s role in Libya is causing growing concern at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a senior official said, with the Kremlin appearing to throw its support behind Gen. Khalifa Haftar, a rival of the United Nations-backed coalition government in Tripoli.

headline: China to Resume Accepting Brazilian Meat
summary: China will reopen its consumer market to Brazilian meat exports, officials in the South American country said, after a scare over alleged corruption in Brazil’s sanitary inspection services prompted major importers to bar shipments.

headline: Jason Gay: Did You See That Florida Shot? It Was Crazy.
summary: A leaping 3-pointer shocks Wisconsin and sends the Gators to a showdown with South Carolina in the Elite Eight.

headline: The Future of Music: Playing for $30,000 in Tips
summary: More up-and-coming musical and comedy acts are using apps like YouNow and Live.ly to live-stream performances, interact with audiences—and rake in virtual-currency tips.

headline: In the Era of Cheap Oil, Gulf Producers Are Forced to Borrow
summary: Some oil producers in the Middle East are weighing taking money up front against future production, as the fall in the price of crude pushes them to look to plug budget holes.

headline: Republicans Look to Rescind Status of National Monument
summary: Even as the tourism industry and visitors embrace Utah’s newly designated national monument, Bears Ears, Republicans are trying to convince President Trump to roll back the protection.

headline: To Stay in Shape, Just Add Squash
summary: A friendly rivalry with rackets fuels regular competition between a brother and sister in Washington, D.C.

headline: Reversing Monument Designation May Prove Rocky for Trump
summary: President Donald Trump could have trouble undoing the actions of former President Barack Obama to abolish the new Bears Ears Monument in Utah.

headline: Dubai Airport Implements U.S. Electronics Ban
summary: Dubai’s airport, the world’s busiest for international traffic, implemented rules banning most carry-on electronics on flights to the U.S., affecting thousands of passengers flying direct to cities across the country.

headline: Greece Receives Three Bids in Long-Running Port Saga
summary: Greece has received three binding bids for a majority stake in its second-largest port in Thessaloniki, the state privatizations agency said, as the country tries to privatize parts of its infrastructure to meet bailout terms.

headline: U.S. Stifles Honduras to Regain World Cup Footing
summary: Recovering from a hole they dug for themselves in November, the U.S. men’s soccer team beat Honduras, 6-0, to move into fourth place in the six-team qualifying tournament for next year’s World Cup.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: Iowa Congressman Faces Pressure From Donors, GOP Backlash for Not Backing Health Bill
summary: David Young ran twice for Congress promising to do whatever he could to repeal the Affordable Care Act. He will find out in next year’s midterm elections if his refusal to support Republican efforts to dismantle the health-care law will cost him his House seat.

headline: With GOP Plan Dead, Trump Weighs Other Ways to Reshape Health Care
summary: With the collapse of the GOP health plan, the Trump administration is set to ramp up its efforts to change the Affordable Care Act in one of the few ways it has left—by altering the law through waivers and rule changes.

headline: A $1 Billion ‘Blank Check’ Is Raised to Shop in the Oil Patch
summary: Investors handed a blank check for $1 billion to a New York investment firm and a retired-energy-CEO-turned-theology-student so they can hunt for an oil business to buy.

headline: A Football Conference Is Taking Over the NCAA Tournament
summary: Kentucky, Florida and South Carolina advanced to the Elite Eight, playing a physical style that mimics their football counterparts in the SEC.

headline: U.S. Farmers Seek Shelter From Nafta Storm
summary: U.S. agricultural producers are lobbying hard on both sides of the Mexico border to try to ensure that a renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement doesn’t turn U.S. farm exports into collateral damage.
